results.title: Game Masters: Fumito Ueda interview
results.creator_credit: Roberto Salvatore, ACMI Content Development and ACMI
results.brief_description:
Fumito Ueda may have only two published games but each one has had such an impact that his influence is felt keenly across the industry. Ueda joined Sony Computer Entertainment in 1997 where he developed his first game, ‘ICO’ (2001), a beautifully poetic adventure game based on an abstracted boy-meets-girl premise. Ueda’s next game, ‘Shadow of the Colossus’ (2005) took an opposing theme to ICO’s sacrificial narrative, with the aim being to topple 16 giant mythical beings to restore the life of a girl named Mono.

NB: This interview was conducted in Fumito Ueda’s native language of Japanese and features English subtitles. Interviewer is neither seen nor heard onscreen.

results.title: King of Maldon
results.creator_credit: Roberto Salvatore, Csilla Csongvay and ACMI
results.brief_description: Glenn Roy, also known as ‘Kinga’, has lived in Maldon for 40 years and is considered a local treasure. Once named the King of Maldon, he takes care of all the elderly in the town doing all sorts of odd jobs for them. He has an obsession for collecting Victor lawnmowers which keeps him busy, as does his dogs and the various bands he performs in. His motto is to be happy and to make sure the town is happy, even if that means putting on a tutu and fishnets for the town’s Mardi Gras Easter parade.

results.title: Game Masters: Hideo Kojima interview
results.creator_credit: Mike Kenneally, ACMI Content Development and ACMI
results.brief_description:
Hideo Kojima speaks about his career as a designer and producer of video games at Konami Digital Entertainment and Kojima Productions. At a time when mainstream action games only focused on attack and defeat, ‘METAL GEAR’ (1987) introduced infiltration into the gameplay and became one of the earliest examples of a stealth game. In 1998, the first 3D title in the ‘Metal Gear’ series, ‘METAL GEAR SOLID’, was released, integrating the most advanced stealth-based gameplay yet seen with cut-scenes that reflected Kojima’s passion for cinema. ‘METAL GEAR SOLID’ became a worldwide best seller and was followed by three successful sequels.

NB: This interview was conducted in Hideo Kojima’s native language of Japanese and features English subtitles. Interviewer is neither seen nor heard onscreen.

results.title: Stories from Yambuk Youth
results.creator_credit: Kim Montgomery, David Withers, Csilla Csongvay and ACMI
results.brief_description: Five boys from Yambuk talk about what it means to be young in a small regional town and the various activities the town has to offer. They tell of the fun times growing up in the country, what they would like to change about the world and their ambitions for the future.

results.title: Marion of Colignan
results.creator_credit: Roberto Salvatore, David Withers and ACMI
results.brief_description: Marion Peters loves living on the land. Despite having the opportunity of establishing a life in the city, she returned to her hometown to raise a family with her husband Geoff on a 12-hectare organic farm that they developed from scratch. Having overcome droughts, hailstorms and the large financial strain of maintaining a farm, Marion feels that things are finally looking up, with a bumper harvest of apples and promising yields of avocadoes and lemons. Marion is heavily involved in giving back to her community, pivotal in fundraising and ensuring community activities are maintained in a small town with a small population. She believes that it is vital for locals to stay involved and active within their own community.

results.title: Game Masters: Alex Rigopulos and Eran Egozy interview
results.creator_credit: Mike Kenneally, ACMI Content Development and ACMI
results.brief_description:
Alex Rigopulos and Eran Egozy talk about their careers designing games at Harmonix Music Systems. While not the first to combine music and videogames, Rigopulos and Egozy were central to the global success of the rhythm genre.

Rigopulos and Egozy’s studio Harmonix’s first two rhythm games, the cult classics ‘Frequency’ (2001) and ‘Amplitude’ (2003), were abstract games with trance-like visuals matched to a gameplay of tight precision. They soon moved on to peripheral-based rhythm games such as ‘Guitar Hero’ (2005), ‘Rock Band’ (2007) and ‘Dance Central’ (2010).

NB: Interviewer is neither seen nor heard onscreen.

results.title: Ouyen's Roxy Theatre
results.creator_credit: Csilla Csongvay, David Withers and ACMI
results.brief_description: The Roxy Theatre in Ouyen was under threat of becoming an abandoned ruin until the community stepped in to save it. Originally opened in 1936, it eventually became one of the only tropical theatres in the southern region of Australia but was closed in 1971 due to the actions of rowdy youths (according to local myth). After 36 years of closure, Jenny Heaslip took on the challenge of restoring the theatre and rallied over 250 local volunteers to help her. It is now an integral meeting point for the people of Ouyen not only because of fortnightly film screenings, but for community events, launches and celebrations. Run on a shoestring budget The Roxy continues to rely upon volunteers and community fundraising to stay alive.

results.title: Horsham Greyhounds
results.creator_credit: Csilla Csongvay, Matt Blackwood and ACMI
results.brief_description: Meet the people that work at the greyhound races every Tuesday afternoon at Horsham, in western Victoria. Mostly volunteers, they assist the dogs and their owners from vets checks to wash downs, ensuring that Horsham Greyhounds remains the safest race in Victoria.

results.title: Meeniyan Junior CFA
results.brief_description: The next generation of fire fighters start young. In an effort to encourage the young people of Meeniyan to become senior CFA members, the Meeniyan Junior CFA creates an atmosphere of fun and friendship while teaching kids the basics of fire fighting.

results.title: The Greta Swamp
results.creator_credit: Csilla Csongvay, David Withers, ACMI Content Development, Shelley Matulick and ACMI
results.brief_description: The area surrounding Greta, in north-eastern Victoria, used to be a swamp, home to indigenous wildlife and the mythical Bunyip creature. The swamp was drained as part of a government employment project in the 1890s, leaving behind rich fertile land ideal for grazing, however it also created a complete change in the area around Greta, especially in the hill country, causing environmental damage. One hundred years on and local Land Care members Anthony and David Griffiths, along with 2012 Land Care President Phil Gottschling, have dedicated their time and energy to try and reverse the effects of the dredging and are revegetating their land to restore balance to the environment.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Csilla Csongvay, David Withers, ACMI Content Development, Shelley Matulick and ACMI
